frame.name: Communication_manner
frame.definition:
<def-root>The words in this frame describe <fen>Manner</fen>s of verbal communication. All of them can occur with quoted expressions.
<ex><fex name="Speaker">He</fex> <t>slurred</t> <fex name="Message">his confession</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition: <def-root>Speaker is the sentient entity that produces a Message or communicates about a Topic. It is expressed as the External Argument of verbs: <ex><fex name="Speaker">The boy</fex> <t>mumbled</t> an apology. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Addressee
FE.definition: <def-root>Addressee is the person to whom the Speaker is communicating. When expressed, the Addressee occurs as a PP Complement: <ex>The taxi driver <t>chattered</t> away <fex name="Addressee">to me</fex> about gardening. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Message
FE.definition: <def-root>Message is the content which is communicated by the Speaker. The Message may be a direct quote, a finite complement clause or an NP Object: <ex><fex name="Message">"I- It was an accident,"</fex> Jo <t>stammered</t>.</ex> <ex> Jo <t>stammered</t> <fex name="Message">that it was an accident</fex>.</ex> <ex> Jo <t>stammered</t> <fex name="Message">an apology</fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition: <def-root>Topic is the subject matter of the communicated Message. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>about</ment> and, in this frame, is frequently preceded by a quantificational noun which is treated as referring to the Message: <ex>The actor <t>chattered</t> <fex name="Topic">about the difficulties of being famous</fex>.</ex> <ex>The person next to me <t>muttered</t> something <fex name="Topic">about pride coming before a fall</fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root>This frame element expresses the medium of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the Message occurs. It is normally expressed as a PP-complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>: <ex>The Beatles <t>sang</t> <fex name="Medium">on the Ed Sullivan show</fex>.</ex> <ex>The drunk man <t>mumbled</t> <fex name="Medium">in French</fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Depictive
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Depictive</fen> is used for any phrase describing a participant in an action. <ex>Jo <t>babbled</t> <fex name="Depictive">in a tuxedo</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Degree</fen> to which an event occurs.</def-root>

FE.name: Result
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Result</fen> of an event.</def-root>

FE.name: Back
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates that the communication act denoted by the target is in response to an earlier communication act in which the roles of <fen>Speaker</fen> and <fen>Addressee</fen> were reversed. This is conceptually akin to the Communication_response frame in which the targets themselves denote the responsive nature of the act.</def-root>

FE.name: Duration
FE.definition: <def-root>The amount of time that the communicative event lasts.</def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition: <def-root>The time at which the communication event takes place.</def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location at which the communication event takes place.</def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition:
<def-root>The action that the <fen>Speaker</fen> performs in order to communicate in the particular way described by the target.
<ex>She could only <t>sing</t> along <fex name="mea">by watching others singing</fex>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: slissen.v
lexUnit.definition: de 's' uitspreken met je tong tussen je tanden

lexUnit.name: schetteren.v
lexUnit.definition: een schel, hard klinkend geluid maken
